#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Become a Street Portrait Artist
#Text=Love the excitement of a crowded street ?
#Text=Want to share the beauty you see in the faces of passersby ?
#Text=These tips will help you launch your new adventure as a street portrait artist today .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Determine what feature of the human face you find most striking .
#Text=Practice quickly sketching that particular feature , be it eyes , noses , chins , cheek bones , etc. , in as much detail and variety as possible .
#Text=Once you 've mastered quickly putting down your favored feature , set a timer and sketch out a completed portrait .
#Text=Perfecting any specific aspect of the portrait creation process will give you the speed necessary to carry your talent to the streets .
#Text=Choose your medium .
#Text=You 'll need a medium that wo n't self-destruct when you hand it off to your client on the street .
#Text=Pencil , water colors , markers , or spray paint will allow you to create a quick , dry , image to sell to your clients without major disruption to their day .
#Text=Select a color palette .
#Text=Speed and high visual impact are the two most important factors when you 're working on the street .
#Text=Choose a narrow spectrum of colors to create your masterpieces ; you wo n't have time to fumble around looking for a fourth tube of paint , a sixth pencil , or a tenth can of spray paint .
#Text=Decide which two to three colors of your favored medium allow you the greatest freedom while delivering the most striking piece of artwork .
#Text=Choose a surface .
#Text=Decide what surface will best suit your medium and provide the greatest ease in creating your on-the-spot portraits .
#Text=People are attracted to the unusual , so give it to them .
#Text=Create your portraits on blocks , or rough chunks , of wood , torn sheets of sandpaper , stones , or paper you 've made yourself .
#Text=Using a textured surface will allow you create a memorable and unique piece of artwork that people will treasure for a lifetime .
#Text=Put together a traveling case for your supplies .
#Text=Determine how many portraits you 'll be able to do in a sitting and pack only the items you 'll require to complete them .
#Text=Choose a case that you can work out of for the greatest ease of set up and tear down , in case you want the freedom to move about to stay in touch with the greatest number of passersby .
#Text=Put your name and contact information in a highly visible location on the traveling case so people can see it while you are working on their portrait .
#Text=Take your talent to the streets with flair .
#Text=Be whoever you imagine yourself to be as you head out onto the streets with your portrait creating traveling case .
#Text=Creative people draw an audience whether they are soundless as they work or make non-stop grunting noises .
#Text=Trust your art and yourself .
#Text=Be gracious and proud of your work .
#Text=Some people will not wish to purchase their portrait once you 've completed it , even if it is utter perfection .
#Text=Thank the person for their time and do n't be put off .
#Text=Display these pieces of art as samples of your talent for your audience to admire .
#Text=Use your fear .
#Text=Fearfulness and trembling hands can help you create the most exceptional portraits , so let your emotions flow as you create .
#Text=Only you , the artist , know what you see in any individual face .
#Text=Only you have an end-product image in your head when you begin .
#Text=Use this to your advantage as you create .
#Text=An errant stroke or fearful jab at your surface with exactly the wrong color may be just the thing that strikes your model as perfection .
#Text=Tips
#Text=People often love to admire raw sketches of an artists work .
#Text=Display a few of what you consider to be your worst and best incomplete efforts to entertain them while you work on their portrait .
#Text=Do n't tell your customer what you think of your sketches , let them tell you what they like .
#Text=Incorporate those things that people seem to like the most into your future portraits .
#Text=Trust your unique talent and perception and let it flow from your hands without limitation .
#Text=If you see evil in a face , allow that evil to shine through in your portrait of them .
#Text=If your eyes detect sadness , let your hands bring that sadness to your portrait surface .
#Text=Allow your art to reveal who you see when you look at that person and you will not go wrong .
#Text=Set your pricing as you see fit .
#Text=Art is personal expression and therefore cannot be governed by others opinions or experiences .

#Text=If you value your work too highly , the worst that can happen is that you end up with great name and talent exposure and a healthy quantity of samples to display for others to enjoy on the street .
#Text=If you place your value too low , the worst that can happen is that you might have to turn away clients due to lack of supplies on hand .
